data.title: Wedding of Prince Gustaf Adolf and Princess Margaret
data.text:
1905 royal wedding

Wedding of Prince Gustaf Adolf and Princess MargaretDate15 June 1905; 119 years ago ( )VenueSt George's Chapel, Windsor CastleLocationWindsor, Berkshire, EnglandParticipants

The wedding of Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, Duke of Scania, and Princess Margaret of Connaught was held on Thursday, 15 June 1905, at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.

The groom was the eldest son of the Crown Prince and Crown Princess of Sweden (later King Gustaf V and Queen Victoria) while the bride was the elder daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Strathearn and the niece of King Edward VII. The couple had met in Egypt earlier that year.

The ceremony was a traditional Church of England wedding service. Philip Eliot, Dean of Windsor, presided at the service and Randall Davidson, Archbishop of Canterbury, conducted the marriage. Guests included members of the British and Swedish royal families, foreign royal families, and dignitaries from both countries.

The couple remained married until Margaret, by then using the Swedish form of her name Margareta, died in 1920 during her sixth pregnancy. Gustaf Adolf remarried her first cousin once removed Lady Louise Mountbatten in 1923 and acceded to the Swedish throne as Gustaf VI Adolf in 1950. Their descendants today form the Swedish, Danish and Greek royal families.

Engagement

[edit]

In January 1905, Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn, and his family, including his two daughters, 23-year-old Princess Margaret and 18-year-old Princess Patricia, visited Portugal. The princesses were considered the most eligible and beautiful in Europe and their uncle, King Edward VII, hoped they would marry a foreign monarch or crown prince. The Connaughts hoped to match one of their daughters with Luís Filipe, Prince Royal of Portugal, but nothing came of the trip and they continued on to Egypt. At a ball held by Abbas II, Khedive of Egypt and Sudan, at Abdeen Palace, the family met Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden and Norway, Duke of Scania, grandson of King Oscar II of Sweden and Norway. Though considered a match for Patricia, Margaret and Gustaf Adolf fell in love at first sight.[1]

After only a few meetings, Prince Gustaf Adolf proposed at a dinner held by the Earl of Cromer, Consul-General to Egypt, on 25 February 1905 at the British Consulate and Margaret accepted.[2] The news came as a surprise in Sweden and the United Kingdom but was received with joy.[citation needed]

On 20 March 1905, King Edward VII granted his formal consent to the marriage pursuant to the Royal Marriages Act 1772. The announcement in The London Gazette read:

HIS MAJESTY was this day pleased to declare His Consent to a Contract of Matrimony between Her Royal Highness Princess Margaret Victoria Augusta Charlotte Norah of Connaught, elder daughter of Their Royal Highnesses The Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Strathearn, and His Royal Highness Prince Oscar Frederick William Olaf Gustavus Adolphus, Duke of Schonen [sic], eldest son of Their Royal Highnesses The Crown Prince and Crown Princess of Sweden and Norway, and grandson of Their Majesties The King and Queen of Sweden and Norway, which Consent His Majesty has caused to be signified under the Great Seal, and to be entered in the Books of the Privy Council.[3]

Wedding

[edit]

The wedding took place in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle. It was a traditional Church of England marriage ceremony conducted according to the Book of Common Prayer. Philip Eliot, Dean of Windsor, presided at the service and Randall Davidson, Archbishop of Canterbury, conducted the marriage, assisted by Herbert Edward Ryle, Bishop of Winchester and Prelate of the Order of the Garter, and Francis Paget, Bishop of Oxford.[citation needed]

The bride was given in marriage by her father. After the service, the couple, the wedding party, and their families and guests returned to Windsor Castle where the register was signed in the White Drawing Room.

The wedding came just days after the dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden was set into motion by a resolution of the Storting on 7 June 1905.[4]

Luncheon

[edit]

After the signing of the register, the King and Queen hosted a luncheon in honour of their niece and her groom. The couple and their families and royal guests dined in the State Dining Room while the other invited guests dined in St George's Hall.[citation needed]

The menu included Zèphires de Crabes á la Suédoise, named in honour of Sweden, and Chaufroix de Cailles à la Bernadotte, named after the Swedish House of Bernadotte. The five-foot-tall wedding cake featured figures bearing wheat, an element on the coat of arms of Sweden symbolizing the House of Vasa.[5]

Honeymoon

[edit]

The couple spent their wedding night at Saighton Grange in Cheshire.[6] From Chester they travelled to Ireland for their honeymoon at Adare Manor in County Limerick, seat of the Earl of Dunraven and Mount-Earl.

Attendants

[edit]

Princess Margaret was attended by four bridesmaids, her sister, Princess Patricia of Connaught, and cousins, Princess Victoria Eugenie of Battenberg, Princess Beatrice of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, and Princess Mary of Wales. Prince Gustaf Adolf's supporters were his brother, Prince Wilhelm, and his uncle, Prince Eugen.

Attire

[edit]

Princess Margaret wore a French-made white satin gown trimmed with orange blossom, myrtle and Irish lace. Her veil, a gift from the ladies of Ireland, later draped her coffin and was removed and given to her daughter Ingrid who wore it at her wedding in 1935. It has subsequently been worn by all of Margaret's female descendants and by her great-granddaughter-in-law, Queen Mary of Denmark. Margaret brought a sprig of myrtle trimmed from a bush planted by her grandmother Queen Victoria with her to Sweden and sprigs from that plant have been carried by every Swedish royal bride since.[citation needed]

Prince Gustaf Adolf wore full dress uniform with the collar and star of the Order of the Bath, the collar and star of the Order of the Seraphim, the riband and star of the Order of the Sword and the neck badge of the Order of the Polar Star.

Gifts

[edit]

The couple received a large number of presents which were displayed at Clarence House, the bride's parent's home. Margaret received several jewels, including two tiaras now in the Swedish royal collection and one by Cartier which now belongs to her granddaughter Queen Anne-Marie of Greece and has been worn by almost all her female descendants on their wedding days. The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire sent a turquoise and diamond brooch now worn by Queen Margrethe II of Denmark. Queen Sofia presented her grandson's bride with a laurel wreath necklace by Boucheron now worn as a tiara by Crown Princess Victoria. King Oscar II gifted the couple Sofiero Palace which became their summer residence.[7]

Exchange of honours

[edit]

On the occasion of the marriage, King Edward VII made Gustaf Adolf's father, Crown Prince Gustaf, a knight of the Order of the Garter.[8] He also made Gustaf Adolf an honorary knight grand cross of both the Order of the Bath and the Royal Victorian Order.[9][10] Gustaf Adolf's brother, Prince Wilhelm, paternal uncle, Prince Eugen, maternal uncle, the Hereditary Grand Duke of Baden, and other Swedish courtiers were also appointed to the Royal Victorian Order.[10] The Khedive, in whose country the couple met, was granted the Royal Victorian Chain.[10]

Gustaf Adolf's grandfather, King Oscar II, made the Prince of Wales and Prince Arthur of Connaught, Margaret's brother, knights of the Order of the Seraphim.[11] Her father, who had had the Seraphim since 1873, was granted the Order of Charles XIII.[12]

Film

[edit]

Cecil Hepworth made a short documentary film of the wedding titled The Royal Wedding at Windsor.[citation needed]

Guests

[edit]

Notable guests in attendance included:[citation needed]

British royal family

[edit]

The Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Strathearn, the bride's parents

Prince Arthur of Connaught, the bride's brother

Princess Patricia of Connaught, the bride's sister

The King and Queen, the bride's paternal uncle and aunt

The Prince and Princess of Wales, the bride's paternal first cousin and the bride's second cousin once removed

Princess Mary of Wales, the bride's paternal first cousin once removed

The Princess Louise, Duchess of Fife, and the Duke of Fife, the bride's paternal first cousin and the bride's third cousin

The Princess Victoria, the bride's paternal first cousin

Princess Beatrice of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, the bride's paternal first cousin

Princess and Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein, the bride's paternal aunt and uncle

The Princess Louise, Duchess of Argyll, and the Duke of Argyll, the bride's paternal aunt and uncle

The Duchess of Albany, the bride's paternal aunt by marriage (also the groom's paternal first cousin once removed)

Princess and Prince Alexander of Teck, the bride's paternal first cousin and the bride's second cousin once removed

The Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, the bride's paternal first cousin

Princess Henry of Battenberg, the bride's paternal aunt

Princess Victoria Eugenie of Battenberg, the bride's paternal first cousin

Swedish royal family

[edit]

The Crown Prince and Crown Princess of Sweden, the groom's parents

The Duke of Södermanland, the groom's brother

The Duke of Västmanland, the groom's brother

The Duke and Duchess of Västergötland, the groom's paternal uncle and aunt

The Duke of Närke, the groom's paternal uncle

Other royal guests

[edit]

The Hereditary Grand Duke and Hereditary Grand Duchess of Baden, the groom's maternal uncle and aunt

Prince and Princess Maximilian of Baden, the groom's maternal first cousin once removed and the bride's half second cousin once removed

Prince and Princess Henry of Prussia, the bride's paternal first cousins (also the groom's maternal first cousin once removed and his wife)

The Duchess and Duke of Sparta, the bride's paternal first cousin (also the groom's maternal first cousin once removed) and the bride and groom's mutual third cousin

Princess and Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse, the bride's paternal first cousin (also the groom's maternal first cousin once removed) and maternal first cousin once removed

The Prince and Princess of Waldeck and Pyrmont, the groom's paternal first cousin once removed and the bride's second cousin once removed

Prince and Princess Christian of Denmark, the groom's second cousins

The Prince and Princess of Wied, the groom's half-second cousin and second cousin

The Hereditary Prince of Hanover, the bride's half second cousin once removed

The Khedive of Egypt and the Sudan

Aftermath

[edit]

The Duke and new Duchess of Scania arrived in Sweden on 8 July 1905 and took up residence in the Royal Palace of Stockholm and Sofiero Palace. The couple had five children: Gustaf Adolf (1906–1947); Sigvard (1907–2002); Ingrid (1910–2000); Bertil (1912–1997); and Carl Johan (1916–2012).[4] Carl Johan was the last surviving great-grandchild of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom.

They remained happily married until Margaret died of sepsis on 1 May 1920 at the age of 38. She was eight months into her sixth pregnancy. In 1923, Gustaf Adolf, by then Crown Prince of Sweden, remarried Margaret's first cousin once removed Lady Louise Mountbatten. He had purposely sought another English wife.[13] He acceded to the Swedish throne as Gustaf VI Adolf in 1950 and died in 1973.

Their descendants today sit on the Swedish and Danish thrones and head the former dynasties of Greece and Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg. Many wedding traditions in these royal families, such as the use of myrtle in bouquets, Margaret's Irish lace veil and the Khedive of Egypt tiara have their origins at this wedding.

See also

[edit]

List of royal weddings
